resources.string:
Seoul is the capital of the Republic of Korea(commonly known as South Korea). Seoul was the capital of Baekje in the past (BC18 ~ AD475) and was the capital of the Joseon Dynasty (1392–1897). Since then, it has been the center of politics, economy, society, and culture, and now about 10 million people (one-fifth of the total population) live in Seoul. The Han River which flows into the center of the city played an important role in Korean history.
\n\nSeoul is a city where past and present coexist. Gyeongbok Palace, Changdeok Palace, Deoksugung Palace, Jongmyo Shrine and the ruins show the historical city with its tradition. The Dongdaemun Design Plaza, where the design begin, Lotte World Tower, the world's fifth tallest building(555m), and the landmark N Seoul Tower, show the modern Seoul.
After the Korean War in the 1950s, it achieved remarkable economic growth for half a century, which is called the miracle on the Han River.

In spring, it is warm enough during the day, but it gets chilly at night. In summer, it is really hot and humid(25 ~ 35 °C). There is a rainy season from late June to early July. It is hottest in the late July and early August. In autumn, it is clear and dry(10 ~ 25°C). The fall foliage reaches a peak in mid-October. In winter, it is too cold. (-10~10°C) December and January are coldest months.
Won (\) is the Korean currency fo money. One dollar (USD) is worth about 1,000 won.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the royal palace of Joseon Dynasty built in the 4th year of King Taejo (1395). It is not only a tourist attraction of history and culture that attracts 5.5 million people annually but also a cultural space for education and leisure where you can learn about the history and culture of the Joseon Dynasty.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was the first of the five palaces built in the Joseon Dynasty (1395). It was destroyed by Japanese Invasion of Korea(1592) but rebuilt during King Kojong(1867). During the Japanese colonial period(1910-1945), much of the palace was destroyed by Japan and Japanese governor-general of Korea was built in the palace. The restoration projects have been promoted since 1989.
Opening hours vary depending on the season. ※ Closed on Tuesdays \n※ You can see Royal Guard Changing Ceremonies at 10:00 and 14:00
Bukchon Hanok Village is a good place to get a quick intro to old Korea. This traditional village is located between Gyeongbok Palace, Changdeok Palace.

Bukchon was a high-class residential area that prime ministers, the royal family inhabited in Joseon Dynasty(1392–1897). The village is composed of many traditional houses, called Hanok and has a history of 600 years. There are museums, craft workshops which allows visitors to experience traditional culture.
Changdeok Palace was the second palace after Gyeongbokgung which had been built in the 5th year of Taejong (1405). Chadeokgung was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1997.

Changdeok Palace is the palace where the kings of the Joseon Dynasty lived for the longest time. It represents the atypical beauty of Korean palace architecture by arranging the buildings along the mountains. It is relatively well preserved in its original form and its harmonious arrangement with nature is excellent. 

 You can see Changdeokgung Palace by moonlight and hear historical information from a guide on an evening tour. This moonlight tour is held in spring and fall and you must reserve the ticket online in advance.(ticket.interpark.com/Global)

 You can visit Huwon(Secret Garden) by making a reservation on the homepage from 10:00 6 days before the desired visit date.
Opening hours vary depending on the season. ※ Closed on Mondays
N Seoul Tower is one of the symbolic landmarks of Seoul. Located on the Namsan Mountain, it provides an amazing 360-degree view of Seoul.

The N Seoul tower was first established as a broadcast tower to send out TV and radio signals in 1969. As of now, it has become one of the representative landmarks and multi-cultural venues in Seoul. There is a cable car that makes it easy to access, but the walk up through the park gives you beautiful sights to see.
Cheonggyecheon Stream is popular places for those seeking recreation and a variety of performances.

In the Cheonggyecheon, large and small events are held almost every week. There is also a music performance and a movie screening day. \n\n Cheonggyecheon Stream passes close to Deoksugung Palace, Seoul Plaza, the Sejong Center, Insadong Street, Changdeokgung Palace, and Changgyeonggung Palace, allowing visitors to easily visit major tourist sites after a leisure stroll along the stream.
City Hall Station (Subway Line 1, 2), Exit 4. Walk 250 m north to Cheonggye Plaza.
The War Memorial of Korea, located in Yongsan-gu, Seoul, exhibits and preserve materials related to the Korean War and serves as a national moral educational venue.

The War Memorial of Korea was established to commemorate the noble sacrifice of patriotic martyrs by the War Memorial Service Korea Society on June 10, 1994. The museum houses approximately 33,000 artifacts with about 10,000 on display at an indoor and outside exhibition halls.

There are six separate indoor halls, including Expeditionary Forces Room, Patriotic Memorial Room, War History Room, 6·25 Korean War Room, Development Hall and Large Machinery Room. The outdoor exhibition hall showcases large-sized weapons.

Visitors of all ages from children to adults can also participate in 20 various educational programs and diverse cultural events such as military music and honor guard events, drawing contest, cultural event and more.
The Lotte World Tower is a supertall skyscraper with a 123-floor, 555 m-high. It opened to the public on April 3, 2017 and is the fifth tallest building in the world as of today.

Lotte World Tower was designed with a conceptual design drawing inspiration from Korean ceramics and Korean writing brushes. The tower contains galleries, cafes, and a luxury hotel, in addition to a sky walk and an observation deck. It will be one of the best spots to appreciate the breathtaking view of Seoul's vibrant city lights.
Jamsil Station (Subway Line 2), Exit 2 \nJamsil Station(Subway Line 8 ), Exit 11
Bongeunsa Temple is a Buddhist temple located across the road from COEX mall and was founded in the 10th year of Silla King Weongseong's reign (794).

Bongeunsa Temple is once known as Gyeonseongsa Temple. In 1498, Queen Jeonghyeon refurbished Gyeonseongsa Temple at the east of King Seongjong\'s royal mausoleum and renamed the temple as Bongeunsa. \nTemple Stay \nTea Ceremony Experience, Temple Tour, 108 Bows, Buddhist Aervice, Buddhist Meal, Interacting with monks and etc.
Bongeunsa Temple Station (Subway Line 9), Exit 1\n Samseong Station (Subway Line 2), Exit 6

Insa-dong is an important place where old but precious and traditional goods are on display. There is one main road in Insa-dong with alleys on each side. Within these alleys are galleries and traditional restaurants, tea houses, and cafes.

Insadong is one of the must-visit neighborhoods in Seoul. You can experience various traditions, such as making crafts using traditional Hanji (traditional handmade paper), trying on Hanbok, making Kimchi.\n\nThere are lots of galleries that show traditional Korean fine art. On the main street and each alley are lots of buildings of arts, crafts, shops, traditional cafes.
Anguk Station (Subway Line 3), Exit 6\n Jonggak Station (Subway Line 1), Exit 3
Dongdaemun Design Plaza (DDP) holds various exhibitions, fashion shows, forums, conferences, and other various cultural events.

Dongdaemun Design Plaza opened in March 2014 is a multi-cultural complex. There are various facilities such as Art halls, Museum, Design Lab, Dongdaemun History & Culture Park. DDP provides diverse contents to experience new design. \n The DDP was designed by Zaha Hadid. She focused on the dynamism fo the Dongdaemun area, which is in a state of constant flux from the early morning to late at night. \n In the night(Fri. Sat. 18:00 ~23:00), Youth Runway Market opens at DDP. You can enjoy diverse foods or exciting performances.
Dongdaemun History & Culture Park Station (Subway Line 2, 4 ,5), Exit 1
Prices vary depending on the exhibition
Hongik University Street (also called Hongdae Street) is known for underground music, clubs, cafes, fashion and art festivals.

Hongdae Street is a energetic neighborhood where lots of young people hang out especially at night. There are lots of street performances, fashion shops, live cafes, restaurants, bars, and clubs.\n\nHongdae Walking Street is a main spot of Hongdae area which has an outdoor stage for indie band performance and dynamic culture of young people.
Hongik University Station (Subway Line 2, Gyeongui-Jungang, AREX), Exit 8 or 9
Jongmyo is a royal shrine dedicated to the performance of ancestral rites for the deceased kings and queens of the Joseon Dynasty.

Being the place where the royal ancestral tablets are enshrined, Jongmyo\'s atmosphere is solemn and sacred rather than splendid like the royal palaces. The simple and elegant buildings of this shrine have faithfully kept their original forms since the 16th century.\n\nFor assistance with reserving a tour of Jongmyo, please call the 1330 Korea Travel Hotline.
English Guide tour - 10:00 12:00 14:00 16:00 ※ Closed on Tuesdays
The Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) is a border zone that divides the Korean Peninsula into South Korea and North Korea.

The Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) is a buffer zone, which was established on July 27, 1953, when the Armistice Agreement was signed during the Korean War. The DMZ vividly captures the scars and wounds of the Korean War as well as the wishes and hopes for the future.

DMZ extends largely from Gyeonggi-do to Gangwon-do, it is advised to make a plan in advance for which region you are most interested in visiting. The Major DMZ tourist destinations in Gyeonggi-do are Imjingak Resort, The Third Tunnel, Dorasan Station, Panmunjeom (Joint Security Area), Unification Hill and Yeolsoe Observatory.

More importantly, you are required to bring a legitimate form of identification and/or your passport when going to the DMZ.

Visitors can only access Panmunjeom by joining a DMZ packaged tour provided by approved travel agencies.

DMZ in Gyeonggi-do: english.gg.go.kr/dmz-imjingak 
International Cultural Service Club website: www.tourdmz.com 
Korea Travel Bureau Inc. website: www.go2korea.co.kr 
Joongang Express Tour website: jsatour.com 
Panmunjeom Travel Center website: www.koreadmztour.com
Bukhansan National Park is a rare urban park in the world. It preserves beautiful natural scenery and cultural resources.

Bukhansan National Park is made up of huge granite. There are dozens of beautiful valleys between the main peaks, more than 1,300 species of flora and fauna are inhabited. It provides a variety of sights and ecological learning places.
215, Bogukmun-ro, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul, Republic of Korea
Gireum Station (Subway Line 4), Exit 3. Take Bus 110B or 143, and get off at the last bus stop.
The National Museum of Korea is the largest museum in Korea and houses precious Korean cultural assets that tell the story of Korea’s fascinating history, from ancient times to the modern era.

In National Museum of Korea, more than 12,044 pieces are always on display in our six permanent exhibition sections. Visitors can examine numerous national treasures of Korea, including Pensive Bodhisattva (Korean National Treasure No.78 or No.83), Goryeo Celadon Openwork Burner (No.95), Ten-Story Pagoda from Gyeongcheonsa Temple-Site (No.86), and Gold Crown from Silla (No.191).
[Mon, Tue, Thu, Fri] 10:00-18:00\n[Wed & Sat] 10:00-21:00\n[Sun & Public Holidays] 10:00-19:00
There are 12 Hangang Citizens\' Park, located along the Han River(Hangang). The Yeouido Hangang Park is the most popular spot for locals and tourists alike.

The Yeouido Hangang Park is a leisure place for citizens to relax. It is a great place for picnics or cycling. There is a public bicycle rental center next to Exit 1 of Yeouido Station. There are many events to enjoy such as spring flower festival, world fireworks festival, various performances and marathon events.
Grevin Museum Seoul is a wax museum, displaying the waxworks of famous and historic people.

The Grevin Museum has 133 years of history and locations in Paris, Prague, and Montreal. The opening of the Seoul location is the museum\'s 4th location worldwide and the first in Asia. \n\nWax figures include celebrities such as John Lennon, Marilyn Monroe, Tom Cruise, Psy, G-Dragon, Yuna Kim, and other Hallyu stars. King Sejong, Yi Sun-shin, and other historical figures are also represented at the museum. In total, there will be about 80 different wax figures.
Trick Eye Museum is a new concept of exhibition space where culture and entertainment are combined. Visitors are invited to explore 3D optical illusion paintings and installations.

Trick Eye is shortened from \'Trick of the eye\' and refers to a traditional art technique Trompe-l\' oeil that turns two-dimensional paintings into three-dimensional images through the use of optical illusions. Paintings on museum walls, floors and ceilings come alive! Visitors are invited to step inside Trick Eye paintings and installations and create their own original stories.
Seogyo Plaza B2, 20, Hongik-ro 3-gil, Mapo-gu, Seoul, South Korea
The Olympic Park built for the 1988 Seoul Olympic Games is a multi-complex for sports, culture, and leisure.

Spread across approximately 1.45 million ㎡, Olympic Park encompasses the land that was once Mongchontoseong Fortress and Mongchonhaeja (manmade lake) from the early Baekje period. The park is divided into several zones: a leisure sports park, a cultural art park, an eco-park, and the History Experience Park dedicated to the area’s rich historic heritage.
Mongchontoseong Station (Subway Line8), Exit 1 \nOlympic Park Station (Subway Line5), Exit 3
Walking/Bicycle : 05:00 ~ 22:00 (~24:00 for Squares)\n Car : 06:00 ~ 22:00 \n※ For safety reasons, any entrance to all park property is NOT allowed except Peace Square and Meeting Square after 22:00.
In Jamsil Baseball Stadium, visitors can experience the ardent fervor and cheering of Korean baseball fans.

Jamsil Baseball Stadium is the home of two teams from the Korean Professional Baseball league, the LG Twins and the Doosan Bears. Even if you do not know about baseball, you can have a good time at Korean baseball stadium. There are lots of singing and dancing and all around good energy for the entire game. You can buy fried chicken and beer and other food.
Jamsil Sports Complex Station(Subway Line 2), Exit 5 or Exit 6
KBO League : March 31 ~ September \nPost Season : October
Prices vary depending on location. 10,000 won ~ 20,000 won
Adjacent to the Gyeongbokgung Palace, the National Folk Museum of Korea presents historical artifacts that were used in the daily lives of Korean people in the past.

The National Folk Museum of Korea has three permanent exhibitions and two special exhibitions as well as a library, souvenir shop, and other subsidiary facilities. Through the displays, visitors can learn about the domestic and agricultural lifestyles, as well as Korea’s cultural beliefs.
Gyeongbokgung Station (Subway Line 3), Exit 5.\nAnguk Station (Subway Line 3), Exit 1.
COEX Aquarium located in COEX shopping mall pursues an entertainment and education where anyone can discover and explore the marvelous ocean world.

The COEX aquarium houses 40,000 sea creatures, which come from 650 different species divided into 16 themed zones. The highest number of sharks and the largest variety of species in Korea are living in the aquarium.
Bongeunsa Station (Subway Line 9), Exit 7\n Samseong Station (Subway Line 2), Exit 6
Siloam Spa, also known as Siloam Bulgama Sauna, is Korean Jjimjilbang. It is a place full of surprises and located within walking distance of Seoul Station.

Siloam Spa is a kind of Jjimjilbang, Korean bathhouse. If you want to find inexpensive accommodation in Seoul, it may be the best choice. You can eat, sleep, and bath here. There are various fomentation rooms and after fomentation you will feel more relaxed.
Good bye.(said to somebody not departing)
Could you take a picture of me, please?
Could you tell me how to get to Gangnam?
How far is it from here?
